user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of has_unprocessed_upload_body_data_in_buffer:
```c
static bool
has_unprocessed_upload_body_data_in_buffer (struct MHD_Connection *c)
{
  mhd_assert (MHD_CONNECTION_BODY_RECEIVING == c->state);
  if (! c->rq.have_chunked_upload)
    return 0 != c->read_buffer_offset;

  /* Chunked upload */
  mhd_assert (0 != c->rq.remaining_upload_size); /* Must not be possible in MHD_CONNECTION_BODY_RECEIVING state */
  if (c->rq.current_chunk_offset == c->rq.current_chunk_size)
  {
    /* 0 == c->rq.current_chunk_size: Waiting the chunk size (chunk header).
       0 != c->rq.current_chunk_size: Waiting for chunk-closing CRLF. */
    return false;
  }
  return 0 != c->read_buffer_offset; /* Chunk payload data in the read buffer */
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No use of any <string.h> functions (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.) appears in this function. The body contains only assertions, simple integer/boolean checks and returns based on structure members (have_chunked_upload, read_buffer_offset, current_chunk_offset, current_chunk_size, remaining_upload_size). Therefore there are no string-handling calls here that could cause out‑of‑bounds accesses under MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. Buffer manipulation or string handling (where the rule would apply) would need to be inspected in other functions that actually perform memcpy/strcpy/etc., but this function contains none of those calls and thus does not need further investigation for Rule 21.17.
